\documentclass[english]{article}
\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}
\usepackage[latin9]{inputenc}
\usepackage{amsmath}
\usepackage{esint}
\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}
With $A\sim B\sim C\sim\text{uniform}\left(0,1\right)$ (i.e. each
distributed uniformly on $\left(0,1\right)$) what is the probability
that the polynomial equation $Ax^{2}+Bx+C=0$ has real roots? The
discriminant should be positive: 
\[
B^{2}-4AC\geq0\iff B^{2}\geq4AC
\]
Taking the log of both sides preserves the inequality since log is
strictly increasing. Then 
\[
2\log\left(B\right)\geq\log\left(4\right)+\log\left(A\right)+\log\left(C\right).
\]
Multiplying everything by a negative sign flips the inequality 
\[
-2\log\left(B\right)\leq-\log\left(4\right)-\log\left(A\right)-\log\left(C\right)
\]
But 
\[
-\log\left(A\right)\sim-\log\left(C\right)\sim\text{exponential\ensuremath{\left(1\right)}}
\]
and 
\[
-2\log\left(B\right)\sim\text{exponential}\left(2\right)
\]
and 
\[
-\log\left(A\right)+-\log\left(C\right)\sim\text{Gamma}\left(2,1\right)
\]
Let $X\sim\text{exponential}\left(2\right)$ and $Y\sim\text{Gamma}\left(2,1\right)$
then question becomes what is $P\left(X<Y+\log\left(1/4\right)\right)$.
By the fact that $P\left(A\right)=E\left(1_{A}\right)=E\left(E\left(1_{A}|X\right)\right)$
and $P\left(A|X\right)=E\left(1_{A}|X\right)$ and then $P\left(A\right)=E\left(P\left(A|X\right)\right)$
it's the case that 
\begin{align*}
P\left(X<Y+\log\left(1/4\right)\right) & =E_{X}\left(P\left(X-\log\left(1/4\right)<Y|X\right)\right)\\
 & =\int_{\log\left(4\right)}^{\infty}P\left(x-\log\left(1/4\right)<Y\right)\left(\frac{1}{2}e^{-x/2}\right)dx\\
 & =\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\int_{x-\log\left(4\right)}^{\infty}\frac{y}{\Gamma\left(2\right)}e^{-y}dy\right)\left(\frac{1}{2}e^{-x/2}\right)dx\\
 & =\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{4}e^{-x}\left(1+x+\log\left(4\right)\right)\right)\left(\frac{1}{2}e^{-x/2}\right)dx\\
 & =\frac{1}{36}\left(5+\log\left(64\right)\right)\approx.254413
\end{align*}
This extends to cubics $Ax^{3}+Bx^{2}+Cx+D$ where the discriminant
is $\Delta=\, B^{2}C^{2}-4AC^{3}-4B^{3}D-27A^{2}D^{2}+18ABCD$ and
other distributions for the coefficients should in principle make
for a tractable problem as well.
\end{document}
